block.p: Canada Moving to Guard Integrity of Its Diamonds Canadian officials, acting to protect their country's emerging diamond industry, are taking steps to ensure that their stones are never confused with the ''blood diamonds'' that help to finance guerrilla armies in Sierra Leone and Angola. For instance, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police are developing a technology to ''fingerprint'' diamonds, identifying them by trace impurities that could be traced to known mines.
Argentine Beef Trade Halted The United States has temporarily halted trade in Argentine beef because of concerns of a possible outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Argentina.

Concordes Stay on the Ground France's transportation minister reiterated that Air France's five remaining Concordes would remain grounded for the time being because of continuing uncertainty about why the supersonic jet caught fire last month and crashed north of Paris.

Effort on Behalf of Pinochet Gen. Augusto Pinochet and his backers have started a campaign to gain public support in helping him avert a trial on charges of kidnapping, murder and torture. An estimated 30 percent of the country still considers the former dictator a hero.

Prague Prepares for I.M.F. Czech officials and private businesses are taking measures to guard against the possibility of violent protests accompanying a meeting of the International Monetary Fund next month.

U.N. Refugee Official Leaving Sadako Ogata, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, plans to retire at the end of the year, and the search is on to find a replacement within the next month or two.

Tourism Grows in Belfast Two neighborhoods in Belfast that were the center of the sectarian violence that held the city hostage for the last 30 years have become a tourist attraction, thanks to murals created by members of both sides of the ''troubles.''

U.S. to Forgo Hearings On EgyptAir 990 Crash The government's top air safey investigator said there were no safety issues that would require a public hearing into the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 last fall, and he disclosed information that reinforced suspicion that a co-pilot deliberately plunged the plane into the Atlantic Ocean off Nantucket, killing all 217 people aboard. The information included F.B.I. reports showing that the co-pilot, Gamil al-Batouti, had been accused of various sexual improprieties at a Manhattan hotel in the year before the crash.
Study of Food-Stamp Process A national network of food banks and advocacy groups said food-stamp applications in most states had become so onerous that needy people were deterred from seeking help.

Assessing Blame for Wildfires Conservative critics -- including the Republican governor of Montana -- said the Clinton administration did not move fast enough to ward off the wildfires burning large chunks of the West. Federal officials and their supporters rejected the accusations.

Cheney's Golden Parachute Halliburton was said to have agreed to give Dick Cheney a retirement package worth about $20 million. Mr. Cheney, who joined the energy services company in 1995, quit as chairman and chief executive last month to join the Republican ticket.

Bush Challenges Gore Gov. George W. Bush called on Vice President Al Gore to emphatically state his disapproval of President Clinton's sexual conduct in office and to send a clear message that he would maintain a high level of integrity if elected president.
Playboy Event Is Moved Representative Loretta Sanchez, bowing to pressure from Democratic Party officials, agreed to move a fund-raiser from the Playboy mansion to Universal Studios.

Buchanan Names Black Woman Patrick J. Buchanan, nominated for president by one faction of the Reform Party, selected as his running mate Ezola Foster, a black woman who taught public school for years in South Central Los Angeles. The party's other faction nominated John Hagelin for president, touching off a fight over who is entitled to $12.6 million in federal campaign funds.

Police Retirements Surge; Discontent Cited as Factor More than 700 police officers have filed for retirement this year, a 38 percent increase over the same seven-month period last year. Department officials say that is a trickle in a department with 40,000 officers, but union leaders say it is the start of a major exodus, as officers seek better-paying, less dangerous jobs where no one calls them names.

Doctor Barred From Practicing The State Department of Health suspended the medical license of Dr. Niels H. Lauersen, a well-known fertility specialist with a busy, celebrity-favored practice; he is facing retrial on insurance fraud charges.

A Campaign Stop on 'Tonight' Hillary Rodham Clinton and Jay Leno bantered gently during her appearance on ''The Tonight Show,'' but she also sought to steer the conversation toward serious subjects integral to her Senate campaign. Mrs. Clinton's three-day campaign and fund-raising schedule will be capped with a prime-time speech to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles on Monday.
Representative Rick A. Lazio scoffed at Mrs. Clinton's assertion that she played a quiet but major role in Clinton administration policy and legislative efforts.

Trade Center Elevator Accident Twelve people were trapped for an hour between the 78th and 79th floors of the World Trade Center after their elevator overshot a floor, hit a ceiling and dropped 15 feet. Injuries included cuts and broken bones.

Assault May Be One of Several A man who sustained head injuries on Thursday in an assault in his Upper West Side apartment may have been attacked by the same person responsible for the burglaries of seven other residences in the area, including several incidents that ended in violence, the police said.
Yanks Hanging On to Clemens Roger Clemens (9-6) is set to sign a contract extension worth $30.9 million over three years.

Rate Rise in Japan The central bank raised interest rates for the first time in a decade, to 0.25 percent for the benchmark overnight call rate, despite pressure from government officials to keep borrowing costs close to zero.
G.M. Looking to Sell Online G.M. is proposing a joint venture with its dealers to establish a Web site offering its own cars -- and those of other makers -- for sale.

Dow Back Above 11,000 The Dow rose 119.04 points, or 1.1 percent, to 11,027.80, its first close above 11,000 since April. The S.& P. 500 gained 11.59 points, to 1,471.84, and the Nasdaq climbed 29.48 points, to 3,789.47.

A Billionaire Recants George Soros, one of the world's most successful speculators and richest men, says in a new book that he was wrong to write in 1998 of the imminent ''disintegration of the global capitalist system.''

Murdoch Seeks Chris-Craft The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, was said to have agreed to acquire Chris-Craft Industries, a television station company, for $3.5 billion. Chris-Craft owns 10 stations, while the News Corporation, which owns the Fox network, has 22 stations.
Editorials: Time for a convention update; Germany's immigration debate; a rescue plan for Camden. Columns: Frank Rich, Anthony Lewis.
